About.orgName: ASKKSA - Shotokan Kokusai Karate Santo Antonio Association
About.orgDescription: ASKKSA is a karate association in Funchal, Madeira, dedicated to the practice and promotion of Shotokan Karate. Founded in 2000, it offers classes for all ages and levels, with a focus on tradition, discipline and excellence.
About.title: About ASKKSA
About.description: ASKKSA, Shotokan Kokusai Karate Association of Santo Antonio, was founded in Funchal in April 2000. The aim of this foundation was, in addition to relaunching the discipline at new levels, to place it within the legal and sporting framework of the Autonomous Region of Madeira. ASKKSA is affiliated with FNK-P (National Karate Federation – Portugal) and AKRAM (Karate Association of the Autonomous Region of Madeira) and is recognised by the DRJD (Regional Directorate of Youth and Sport).

instructors.title: Our Team of Excellence
instructors.subtitle: ASKKSA is proud to have a team of elite instructors, highly qualified and with extensive experience in Shotokan Karate. All have recognised national and international training, ensuring teaching of the highest quality.

dojos.title: Our Dojos
dojos.subtitle: We currently offer two modern training spaces in Funchal, equipped with all necessary conditions for the practice of Shotokan Karate. Additionally, we provide specialised technical support to the Câmara de Lobos Sports Club.

hallBlackBelts.title: Hall of Black Belts
hallBlackBelts.subtitle: ASKKSA is proud to have a select group of practitioners who have achieved the prestigious rank of Black Belt. These karatekas exemplify the dedication, discipline, and excellence that define our association.

meta.title: In the Dojo | Etiquette and Traditions | ASKKSA Karate Madeira

InDojo.name: ASKKSA: Shotokan Kokusai Karate Santo Antonio Association
InDojo.title: In the Dojo
InDojo.introduction: In the Dojo, the heart of Karate, we practise and live by the guiding principles. Here, tradition meets discipline, and each training session is an opportunity for personal growth.

salutation.title: Salutation
salutation.description: The salutation in Karate is an expression of sincerity (SEIJITSU), which is part of the ethical code of the martial art. It is a sign of a karateka who does not conceal their ideals and feelings and is able to be themselves.

rules.title: Rules
rules.description: The Dojo is the place where the teachings of the martial art are passed on to practitioners; as such, it must be a place where seriousness and respect prevail.

vocabulary.title: Vocabulary
vocabulary.description: As Karate is a martial art of Japanese origin, it is natural that many of the terms used in the Dojo are Japanese.

grades.title: Grades
grades.description: Martial arts from Japan and Okinawa feature a variety of titles and grades.

philosophy.title: Life in the Dojo
philosophy.description: The dojo is not just a place for physical training, but a sacred space where spirit is cultivated, discipline is learned and character is forged. Each element – from the salutation to the rules of etiquette – helps create an environment of mutual respect and personal growth.

meta.title: Karate Salutation | OSS and Rituals | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the meaning of salutation in Shotokan Karate, the word OSS and the rituals at the start and end of training. SEIJITSU, Mokuso, Seiza.
meta.keywords: Karate Salutation, OSS, Dojo Rituals, Seijitsu, Mokuso, Seiza, Shomen ni Rei, Sensei ni Rei, Karate Etiquette, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan

Salutation.title: Salutation
Salutation.introduction: The salutation in Karate is an expression of sincerity (SEIJITSU) that forms part of the ethical code of the martial art. It is a sign of a karateka who does not hide their ideals or feelings and is able to be themselves. Salutation in class, whether a simple OSS, greeting the training partner or even the ritual at the start or end of training, is of great importance for all those who wish to experience Karate in its purest and deepest form.
Salutation.description: Upon entering the dojo, we greet the Sensei and fellow practitioners, recognising the importance of mutual respect and discipline.

oss.title: The word "OSS"
oss.origin: Derived from the Japanese word Ossishinobu, equivalent to our good morning or good afternoon, it is a greeting full of patience, respect and appreciation, and can have different meanings depending on intonation.
oss.creation: The expression OSS was created at the Japanese Naval Academy and is universally used for everyday expressions such as "yes", "please", "thank you", "understood", "excuse me", to greet someone, etc., as well as in the world of Karate for almost any situation where a response is required.
oss.importance: For a karateka, OSS is the most important word. OSS means pushing oneself to the limit of one’s capacity and enduring.
oss.meaning: OSS means, quite simply, "perseverance under pressure". It is a word which in itself sums up the philosophy of Karate.
oss.spirit: A good Karate practitioner is one who cultivates the "spirit of OSS".

steps.meaning: Let us strive spiritually in this form of karate
Thank you very much for the training, Sensei.

salutation.title: Formal Salutation
salutation.text: Practitioners should salute the Sensei and fellow students when entering and leaving the dojo.

meta.title: Dojo Rules | Etiquette and Conduct | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Learn the conduct and etiquette rules of the Shotokan Karate dojo. Behaviour, respect and Japanese traditions. ASKKSA Funchal.
meta.keywords: Dojo Rules, Karate Etiquette, Dojo Conduct, Respect, Japanese Traditions, Sensei, Karate Discipline, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan

DojoRules.title: Dojo Rules
DojoRules.introduction: The Dojo is the place where the teachings of the martial art are passed on to practitioners; as such it must be a place where seriousness and respect prevail. In ASKKSA dojos, the traditional rules of good conduct characteristic of Japanese dojos, the place of Karate's origin, are followed.
DojoRules.description: Therefore, it is important that every karateka understands that within the training area (and preferably in all other daily situations) they should behave according to the moral heritage of this martial art. The rules below must be understood and respected by all practitioners in our dojos.

responsibility.title: Care and Respect for the Training Space
responsibility.rule1: The DOJO is the responsibility of all who use its space. Feel at home to provide information to visitors, tidy what is untidy, and clean what is dirty.
responsibility.rule2: Contribute as much as you can to the improvement of the club’s facilities.

hygiene.title: Hygiene and Personal Presentation
hygiene.rule1: Maintain personal hygiene and keep your Karate-Gi (Kimono) clean.
hygiene.rule2: Always enter the training area with clean hands and feet and well-trimmed nails.
hygiene.rule3: Do not wear jewellery (rings, earrings, bracelets, watches), strong perfumes or any accessory that might interfere with your training or that of your partners.
hygiene.rule4: Do not walk around the Dojo without being fully dressed.

entrance.title: Entering and Leaving the Dojo
entrance.rule1: When entering and leaving the training area always salute standing to the space.
entrance.rule2: If you arrive after the class has started, enter quietly, sit in SEIZA, and ask permission from the highest-ranked instructor to join the training. After their permission, salute and join the group.
entrance.rule3: If you really need to leave before the end of training, always ask permission from the instructor/monitor. NEVER leave during training without their authorisation.

behavior.title: Behaviour During Classes
behavior.rule1: Maintain silence and concentration during training.
behavior.rule2: When the instructor/monitor is demonstrating a technique, remain seated, silent and attentive. If you do not understand well, watch others, try the little you have understood, and wait for correction by the instructor.
behavior.rule3: If it is absolutely necessary to ask the instructor/monitor something, call them quietly by raising your right arm. Never shout to get their attention.
behavior.rule4: Always sit in SEIZA or cross-legged. Do not sit leaning against the wall or in any other position. Always maintain good posture in all situations.
behavior.rule5: Never use your mobile phone inside the dojo during training times.
behavior.rule6: Even outside the class area, keep silent during training and do not talk to those who are training.

instructors.title: Relationship with Instructors
instructors.rule1: Inside the dojo, NEVER address instructors by their first name, even if you have a close relationship with them. The most appropriate is to call them Sensei (Teacher).
instructors.rule2: Train exactly as instructed by the instructor/monitor. If you wanted to do it your own way, you would not need to come to the dojo.
instructors.rule3: Never argue with the instructor/monitor, even if another instructor said something different. There are various ways to perform techniques and different instructors may have had different training experiences, which does not mean any of them are wrong. You should simply follow each instructor, in each lesson, to the best of your ability.

training.title: Training and Relationship with Partners
training.rule1: Do not refuse to train with any partner when directed by the instructor.
training.rule2: Help those who need it, but never correct your partner unless you are the instructor/monitor of the class and/or a black belt.
training.rule3: Never think you are disturbing anyone by not knowing how to perform a technique. We are all learning, helping each other.
training.rule4: Respect higher-ranked students (especially black belts) and never argue whether techniques are right or wrong. Remember that they did not reach their rank by mere chance.
training.rule5: Train diligently and energetically but always respect your partner’s physical integrity. Classes always include people of different genders, ages and physical abilities. While the ideal is to train as vigorously as possible, the physical capacities and training goals of each partner must be considered. Everyone has different conditions and reasons for training. We must respect their expectations.
training.rule6: Be aware of what is happening around you. Adjust the intensity of your movements to your physical condition. Take responsibility for yourself.
training.rule7: Do not skip any technique (unless injured).

practical.title: Practical and Health Aspects
practical.rule1: If you have any injury or physical limitation, you must inform the instructor before starting training.
practical.rule2: Avoid attending classes if you have any contagious illness spread by air or contact.
practical.rule3: Do not be late or fail to pay fees. If you need to be absent for a while due to travel or illness, inform the instructor. Remember your contribution is necessary to cover the expenses of running a karate dojo.

meta.title: Japanese Karate Vocabulary | Dojo Terms | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Learn the essential Japanese vocabulary of Shotokan Karate. Numbers, counters and dojo terms. Hiragana, Katakana, Kanji.
meta.keywords: Japanese Karate Vocabulary, Dojo Terms, Japanese Numbers, Karate Language, Hiragana Katakana Kanji, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan, Japanese Martial

Vocabulary.title: Japanese Vocabulary
Vocabulary.introduction: As Karate is a martial art of Japanese origin, it is natural that many of the terms used in the Dojo are Japanese. Although these words may seem strange to new practitioners at first, with time and practice they become part of every karateka’s daily life.
Vocabulary.description: It should be noted that the Japanese use three writing systems (Hiragana, Katakana and Kanji) in their daily lives. To make things easier for new practitioners, we present the most commonly used vocabulary in karate dojos around the world.

otherCounters.title: Other Counters
otherCounters.subtitle: hon (various types of objects, especially long and thin, but also techniques or sets of techniques, practice sessions, etc.)

vocabulary.title: Most Common Words
vocabulary.aihanmi: Relative stance of two practitioners with the same leg forward
vocabulary.budo: Way of the warrior, martial arts
vocabulary.chi: Chinese word for vital energy, same as "Ki"
vocabulary.chudan: Middle level (from the neck to the waist)
vocabulary.gasho: Place hands together in front of the face to bow (Zen, Mokuso, etc.)
vocabulary.gi: Suit for Budo practice, made up of Uwagi (jacket), Zubon (trousers) and Obi (belt)
vocabulary.gonosen: Tactic of letting the opponent attack first in order to counter-attack
vocabulary.hakama: Wide trousers worn over the gi in traditional martial arts (Kyudo, Kendo, Iaido, Aikido, etc.)
vocabulary.hikite: Drawing the fist back to the hip
vocabulary.horanokamae: Starting position of some katas, with one hand covering the closed fist
vocabulary.jiyuipponkumite: Free (controlled) sparring with a single attack
vocabulary.jiyukumite: Controlled partner exercises in which sparring forms are free
vocabulary.joseki: Upper side, place of honour (in the dojo, the south wall, to the right of the main wall)
vocabulary.kamiza: Main wall of the dojo, to the east, where the Tokonoma is
vocabulary.karatedo: The Way of the empty hands
vocabulary.kata: Form of practice, with or without a partner, with pre-set sequences of techniques
vocabulary.kiai: Projection of energy through a shout
vocabulary.kime: Concentration of physical and mental energy, decision
vocabulary.kohai: Junior practitioner, the opposite of Sempai
vocabulary.makikomi: Judo technique consisting of throwing by rolling the opponent
vocabulary.makiwara: Traditionally straw-wrapped target for training Karate-do or Kyudo
vocabulary.midale: Karate-do training method consisting of continued attacks and dodges
vocabulary.mokuso: Literally: not thinking. State of concentration during the opening and closing ceremony of Budo practice
vocabulary.nukite: Attack with fingers together and extended
vocabulary.shimoza: West wall of the dojo, opposite Kamiza, where the students sit
vocabulary.shimoseki: North wall of the dojo, where non-practising assistants may sit
vocabulary.shinai: Bamboo sword used in Kendo practice
vocabulary.shomenrei: Bow to the main wall of the dojo
vocabulary.shomentaishi: Bow towards the main wall of the dojo
vocabulary.shuto: Edge of the hand (little finger side)
vocabulary.sokuto: Edge of the foot, little toe side
vocabulary.sutemi: Sacrifice; techniques in which the executor throws themselves to throw the opponent
vocabulary.tatami: Japanese mat covering the floor, used in Judo and Aikido
vocabulary.tettsui: Outer lateral part of the fist
vocabulary.tomarite: Combat techniques originating in Tomari - Okinawa
vocabulary.tonfa: Agricultural tool used in popular fighting techniques
vocabulary.tori: The one who attacks, the executor
vocabulary.tsukuri: Contact, second phase of executing a Judo technique
vocabulary.uke: The attacker, in two-person practice; the one who receives the fall
vocabulary.zen2: Japanese discipline, a branch of Buddhism

hiragana.title: Hiragana (ひらがな)
hiragana.description: Syllabic script used for native Japanese words and grammatical particles

katakana.title: Katakana (カタカナ)
katakana.description: Syllabic script used for words of foreign origin and onomatopoeia

kanji.title: Kanji (漢字)
kanji.description: Chinese characters adapted and integrated into Japanese writing

meta.title: Karate Grades | Kyu and Dan System | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the Shotokan Karate grading system: Kyu, Dan, belt colours and symbolism. System created by Jigoro Kano. ASKKSA Funchal.
meta.keywords: Karate Grades, Kyu Dan System, Karate Belts, Jigoro Kano, Karate Belt Colours, Black Belt, Karate Ranks, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan

Graduations.title: Graduations
Graduations.introduction: Martial arts from Japan and Okinawa feature a variety of titles and grading classes. The current system of coloured belts is the most widely accepted. Before this, many different methods were used to mark the various levels of practitioners.
Graduations.description: The current system governing Karate, using Kyu (class) and Dan (degree), was founded by Jigoro Kano, founder of Judo Kodokan. Kano was an educator and understood people, knowing that many need encouragement immediately after beginning a martial art. The anxiety of this type of practitioner could not be satisfied with only long-term goals.

system.title: Kyu and Dan Grading System
system.founder: System founded by Jigoro Kano, founder of Judo Kodokan
system.purpose: Created to provide immediate encouragement for those starting martial arts practice
system.motivation: The anxiety of practitioners could not be satisfied only with long-term goals

symbolism.title: Symbolism of the Colours
symbolism.description: In this colour classification and on a symbolic level:
symbolism.white: White means the purity of the beginner
symbolism.black: Black refers to the refined knowledge gained after years of training

kyu.title: Kyu Grades (Class)
kyu.description: Kyu grades represent student levels, normally identified by coloured belts

dan.10: 10th Dan – Tenth degree – Attainable only by exemplary masters
dan.title: Dan Grades (Degree)
dan.description: In the black belt classification, the first is called 1st Dan, the second 2nd Dan and so on in ascending order up to 10th Dan, attainable only by exemplary masters who have dedicated their lives to Karate.

timeline.title: Dedication Time
timeline.description: The grading system recognises the time and dedication required to master Karate
timeline.journey: Each grade represents a stage in the karateka’s journey
timeline.mastery: The highest grades are attainable only by masters who have dedicated their lives to Karate

meta.title: History of Karate | ASKKSA Shotokan Karate Madeira
meta.description: Discover the rich history of Karate, from its origins in Okinawa with Sokon Matsumura to Gichin Funakoshi. Kihon, Kumite and Kata explained.
meta.keywords: Karate History, Gichin Funakoshi, Sokon Matsumura, Okinawa, Kihon Kumite Kata, Shotokan Karate, Budo, ASKKSA Madeira, Japanese Martial Art

History.name: ASKKSA: Shotokan Kokusai Karate Santo Antonio Association
History.title: History of Karate

introduction.text: Karate or karate-do is a form of budo (way of the warrior). It is a Japanese martial art that originated in Okinawa and was introduced to the main islands of the Japanese archipelago in 1922. Karate emphasises striking techniques (such as punches and kicks) over grappling techniques.

threePillars.title: The Three Pillars of Practice
threePillars.subtitle: Karate practice is based on three fundamental components:

kihon.title: Kihon (基本):
kihon.description: The study and repetition of basic movements, the foundation of all technique.

kumite.title: Kumite (組手):
kumite.description: Means "sparring" and is the practical application of techniques with a partner, performed either in a set form or freely (randori).

kata.title: Kata (型):
kata.description: Means "form" and is a sequence of movements simulating a fight against imaginary opponents, essential for the development of technique and spirit.

origins.title: Origins and Evolution
origins.content: Originally, the word "karate" was written with ideograms meaning "Chinese hand" (唐手), reflecting the influence of the Tang dynasty. Today, the more common meaning is "empty hand" (空手), and Karate-do translates as "the way of the empty hand". It is believed the art is a fusion of Chinese fighting techniques, brought to Okinawa by merchants, with the native Okinawan fighting art known as Te (hand).
origins.matsumura: In 1820, master Sokon Matsumura blended the local styles (Shuri-te, Naha-te and Tomari-te), but it was his own students who, by perfecting and adapting the techniques, created new variations. It was Gichin Funakoshi, a student of one of Matsumura’s disciples, who introduced and popularised Karate in mainland Japan.

modernization.title: Modernisation in Japan
modernization.funakoshi: Funakoshi was responsible for changing the written name to "empty hand", a strategic move to integrate the art into Japanese budo culture and distance it from foreign origins during a period of strong nationalism. Karate was popularised and introduced in secondary schools before the Second World War.
modernization.transition: Like many Japanese martial arts, Karate made its transition to Karate-do at the start of the 20th century. The "do" (way) brings deep elements of Zen Buddhism to practice, sometimes called "Zen in motion". Modernisation also included the adoption of the white uniform (keikogi) and coloured belts to indicate grade, both popularised by Jigoro Kano, founder of Judo.

meta.title: Karate Philosophy | Bushido, Niju, Dojo Kun | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the philosophy of Shotokan Karate through Bushido, Niju Kun and Dojo Kun. Ancient principles of discipline, respect, and self-control.
meta.keywords: Karate Philosophy, Bushido, Niju Kun, Dojo Kun, Gichin Funakoshi, Samurai Code, Karate Principles, Karate Ethics, ASKKSA Madeira, Discipline, Respect

Philosophy.name: ASKKSA: Shotokan Kokusai Karate Santo Antonio Association
Philosophy.title: Karate Philosophy
Philosophy.introduction: The philosophy of Shotokan Karate is rooted in ancient principles that shape not only technique but also the character and essence of the practitioner. Discover the ethical and moral foundations that guide every karateka on their journey of self-discovery.

bushido.title: Bushido – Code of Ethics
bushido.description: The nine fundamental ethical principles inspired by the Samurai code: honour, loyalty, sincerity, courage, kindness, modesty, justice, respect, and self-control.

nijuKun.title: Niju Kun – 20 Principles
nijuKun.description: The twenty principles developed by Master Gichin Funakoshi which form the philosophical and spiritual foundation for all practitioners of Shotokan Karate.

dojoKun.title: Dojo Kun – 5 Maxims
dojoKun.description: The five fundamental maxims established by Master Funakoshi for everyone who enters a sacred place of training – the Dojo.

importance.title: Philosophy as a Pillar of Karate
importance.description: The philosophy of Karate is not limited to physical techniques, but encompasses a profound moral and ethical code that guides the practitioner both inside and outside the dojo. These ancient teachings form the solid foundation of the personal, spiritual, and inner growth of each karateka.

meta.title: Bushido | 9 Samurai Principles | ASKKSA Karate Madeira
meta.description: Discover the Bushido code in Shotokan Karate. The 9 samurai principles: honour, loyalty, courage, justice, and self-control. ASKKSA Funchal.
meta.keywords: Bushido Karate, Samurai Code, 9 Principles, Honour, Loyalty, Courage, Justice, Self-control, Karate Philosophy, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan

Bushido.title: Bushido Code of Ethics
Bushido.introduction: Bushido, or the "Way of the Warrior", is the moral code of the samurai that was adapted to Shotokan Karate. This code represents the fundamental values that every practitioner should cultivate.
Bushido.description: The nine principles of Bushido form the ethical foundation of our practice, guiding the development of character both inside and outside the dojo. Each principle represents an essential virtue for personal and spiritual growth.

honor.name: Honour
honor.description: Personal dignity and moral integrity that guide all the actions of the karateka

loyalty.name: Loyalty
loyalty.description: Faithfulness to the principles, the dojo, the instructors and training partners

sincerity.name: Sincerity
sincerity.description: Honesty with oneself and with others in all circumstances

courage.name: Courage
courage.description: Bravery to face challenges and defend the right principles

kindness.name: Kindness
kindness.description: Compassion and benevolence in dealing with all beings

modesty.name: Modesty
modesty.description: Humility and simplicity, always recognising there is much to learn

justice.name: Justice
justice.description: Moral rectitude and fairness in all decisions and actions

respect.name: Respect
respect.description: Consideration and reverence for oneself, others and traditions

selfControl.name: Self-control
selfControl.description: Mastery over one’s own emotions, impulses and reactions

meta.title: Niju Kun | 20 Principles of Gichin Funakoshi | ASKKSA Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 20 fundamental principles of Shotokan Karate (Niju Kun) developed by Master Gichin Funakoshi. Philosophy and timeless teachings.
meta.keywords: Niju Kun, 20 Karate Principles, Gichin Funakoshi, Karate Philosophy, Funakoshi Teachings, Shotokan Principles, ASKKSA Madeira, Traditional Karate

NijuKun.title: Niju Kun – The 20 Principles
NijuKun.introduction: Sensei Gichin Funakoshi developed and refined twenty principles that should form the philosophical foundation for all Karate practitioners. He called these teachings Niju Kun.
NijuKun.description: These fundamental principles guide not only the practice of Karate, but also the way we should live our lives with honour, respect and discipline.

greeting.title: 1. Greeting
greeting.description: Karate begins with a bow and ends with a bow.

noOffense.title: 2. No Offence
noOffense.description: In Karate there is no offensive attitude.

justice.title: 3. Path of Justice
justice.description: Whoever practises Karate must follow the path of justice.

selfKnowledge.title: 4. Self-Knowledge
selfKnowledge.description: Know yourself before you judge others.

spiritDevelopment.title: 5. Development of Spirit
spiritDevelopment.description: The development of the spirit is most important; technical skill is only a means to that end.

mentalControl.title: 6. Mental Control
mentalControl.description: Avoid loss of mental balance, control your mind.

lifeLongTraining.title: 8. Lifelong Training
lifeLongTraining.description: Karate training lasts a lifetime, not just the initiation.

applyKarate.title: 9. Apply Karate
applyKarate.description: Use Karate in all things you do.

hotWater.title: 10. Hot Water
hotWater.description: Karate is like hot water. If you do not constantly heat it, it becomes cold.

notBeDefeated.title: 11. Do Not Be Defeated
notBeDefeated.description: Do not think of winning, think of not being defeated.

strengthWeakness.title: 12. Strengths and Weaknesses
strengthWeakness.description: Victory depends on being able to distinguish strengths (JITSU) from weaknesses (KYO).

sharpSwords.title: 14. Sharp Swords
sharpSwords.description: Imagine your opponent’s limbs as sharp swords.

millionOpponents.title: 15. Millions of Opponents
millionOpponents.description: For every man who leaves home, millions of opponents await.

artificialToNatural.title: 16. Artificial to Natural
artificialToNatural.description: At first, movements are artificial, but with progress they become natural.

correctPractice.title: 17. Correct Practice
correctPractice.description: Practise correctly what you have been taught; be aware that in application it becomes different.

forceControl.title: 18. Control of Force
forceControl.description: Do not forget to apply correctly: 1) Strength and weakness in controlling your force; 2) Expansion and contraction of the body; 3) Control of techniques in both slowness and speed.

studyPractice.title: 19. Study and Practise
studyPractice.description: Always study, practise and improve yourself.

footer.title: Live the Principles
footer.message: These 20 principles of Niju Kun are more than rules for the dojo – they are a guide to a life of integrity, respect and continual growth.

meta.title: Dojo Kun | 5 Maxims of Funakoshi | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 5 fundamental maxims of the Dojo Kun developed by Master Gichin Funakoshi. Essential principles for all Karate practitioners.
meta.keywords: Dojo Kun, 5 Karate Maxims, Gichin Funakoshi, Dojo Philosophy, Dojo Precepts, Karate Principles, ASKKSA Madeira, Shotokan, Dojo Etiquette

DojoKun.title: Dojo Kun – The 5 Maxims
DojoKun.introduction: Master Gichin Funakoshi developed and refined five sacred maxims that he considered essential for everyone entering a place of training – the Dojo. He called these commandments the Dojo Kun.
DojoKun.description: These five fundamental maxims establish the moral and ethical principles that should guide all practitioners inside the dojo, creating an environment of respect, discipline and personal growth.

character.title: HITOTSU JINKAKU KANSEI NI TSUTOMURU KOTO
character.description: Character (Strive for the perfection of character)

sincerity.title: HITOTSU MAKOTO NO MICHI O MAMORU KOTO
sincerity.description: Sincerity (Be faithful to the path of truth)

effort.title: HITOTSU DORYOKU NO SEISHIN O YASHINAU KOTO

selfControl.title: HITOTSU KEKKI NO YU O IMASHIMURU KOTO

footer.title: The Spirit of the Dojo
footer.message: These five maxims of the Dojo Kun are actively followed in every training session, reminding us of the fundamental values that should guide our practice and our lives.

meta.title: 26 Shotokan Katas | Gichin Funakoshi | ASKKSA Shotokan Madeira
meta.description: Discover the 26 Shotokan Karate katas of Gichin Funakoshi. Heian, Tekki, Bassai, Kanku – traditional forms preserved for generations.
meta.keywords: Shotokan Katas, 26 Katas, Heian Shodan, Tekki Bassai, Kanku, Gichin Funakoshi, Karate Forms, ASKKSA Madeira, Traditional Kata

ShotokanKatas.name: ASKKSA: Shotokan Kokusai Karate Santo Antonio Association
ShotokanKatas.title: Shotokan – 26 Katas
ShotokanKatas.introduction: The Shotokan style, founded by Sensei Funakoshi, currently has 26 katas that are studied over a lifetime of training.
ShotokanKatas.description: Each kata represents a unique form of imaginary combat, preserving ancient techniques and the philosophies of traditional Karate. Katas are the essence of Karate, combining movement, breathing and spirit.

kanku_dai.name: KANKU DAI (観空大)
kanku_dai.meaning: GAZE AT THE SKY (kan=look, ku=nothingness, emptiness, sky) – Long

gankaku.name: GANKAKU (岩鶴)
gankaku.meaning: CRANE ON THE ROCK (gan=rock, kaku=crane upon)

jion.name: JION (慈恩)
jion.meaning: LOVE and GRATITUDE (ji=universal love, tender, gentle; on=love, benevolence, kindness)

sochin.name: SOCHIN (壯鎭)
sochin.meaning: UNSHAKEABLE PEACE (so=robust, vigorous, energetic, chin=suppress, remain calm)

jiin.name: JIIN (慈陰)
jiin.meaning: PROTECTIVE LOVE (ji=universal love, tender, gentle, in=shade)

footer.title: A Lifetime of Study
footer.message: The 26 Shotokan katas represent a complete universe of martial knowledge. Each kata has its own personality, history and lessons to teach, providing a lifetime path of learning.

meta.title: Frequently Asked Questions | Karate Classes Funchal | ASKKSA Madeira
meta.description: Get answers about karate classes in Funchal. Free trial, prices, schedules, kids & adult classes. Learn Shotokan Karate at ASKKSA, Madeira's leading dojo.
meta.keywords: karate classes Funchal, karate prices Madeira, kids karate Funchal, adult karate classes, free karate trial, Shotokan Karate costs, martial arts Funchal, ASKKSA FAQ

FAQ.title: Frequently Asked Questions
FAQ.subtitle: Everything you need to know about starting your Shotokan Karate journey at ASKKSA in Funchal, Madeira.

q1.question: Where can I learn karate in Funchal, Madeira?
q1.answer: ASKKSA has two main dojos in Funchal: our primary location at Escola Horácio Bento de Gouveia (Santo António) and at the Santo António Parish Council. We also provide technical support to Câmara de Lobos Sports Club. All our facilities are modern, safe, and equipped for traditional Shotokan Karate training.

q2.question: Is the first karate class really free?
q2.answer: Yes! We offer 3 FREE trial classes so you can experience our teaching methodology, meet our qualified instructors, and see if Shotokan Karate is right for you or your child. No commitment required. Just contact us at (+351) 960 384 090 or direcao@askksa.pt to book your free trial.

q3.question: How much does karate cost per month in Madeira?
q3.answer: Our monthly membership is €25, which includes all training sessions throughout the week. This is exceptional value for classes led by nationally certified instructors (up to Grade III coaches) with direct lineage from SKIF Canada. We believe quality martial arts training should be accessible to everyone.

q4.question: What are the karate class schedules in Funchal?
q4.answer: We train Monday to Friday. Children (up to 12 years) train from 19:30 to 20:30, and adults (12+ years) train from 20:30 to 21:30. Our schedule is designed to accommodate families, students, and working professionals in the Funchal area.

q5.question: Can my child start karate? What age is best?
q5.answer: Absolutely! We welcome children from age 5 onwards. Karate is excellent for developing discipline, focus, confidence, and physical fitness in young people. Our specialized children's classes use age-appropriate teaching methods and focus on building character alongside martial arts skills. Many parents in Funchal choose ASKKSA specifically for our proven track record with children's development.

q6.question: Do you offer karate classes for adults and beginners?
q6.answer: Yes! Adults of all fitness levels and experience are welcome, including complete beginners. Whether you're looking to learn self-defense, improve fitness, or explore traditional martial arts, our adult classes (20:30-21:30) provide structured training in authentic Shotokan Karate. You're never too old to start—we have students ranging from teenagers to seniors.

q7.question: What is Shotokan Karate and how is it different?
q7.answer: Shotokan is one of the most traditional and widely practiced styles of karate worldwide. It emphasizes powerful linear techniques, deep stances, and kata (formal patterns). ASKKSA follows the SKIF (Shotokan Karate International Federation) lineage, ensuring you learn authentic techniques directly from the Japanese tradition. Our instructors are internationally certified by SKIF Canada.

q8.question: Are your karate instructors qualified and certified?
q8.answer: Absolutely. All ASKKSA instructors hold national coaching certifications from FNK-P (Portuguese National Karate Federation) ranging from Grade I to Grade III. Our head instructor, Shihan Jorge Freitas, holds 6th DAN and has over 40 years of experience. We also have several 4th and 5th DAN certified instructors. All are graduates of SKIF Canada and SKIF, ensuring world-class instruction.

q9.question: What do I need to bring to my first karate class?
q9.answer: For your free trial classes, just wear comfortable athletic clothing (t-shirt and sweatpants or shorts). You'll train barefoot. If you decide to continue, you'll need a karate-gi (uniform), which we can help you obtain. We'll also provide guidance on proper care and etiquette.

q10.question: Is ASKKSA affiliated with official karate organizations?
q10.answer: Yes, ASKKSA is officially affiliated with FNK-P (Federação Nacional de Karate Portugal), AKRAM (Associação de Karate da Região Autónoma da Madeira), and recognized by DRJD (Regional Directorate of Youth and Sport). We are also members of SKIF (Shotokan Karate International Federation), connecting you to a global network of traditional karate practitioners.

q11.question: Can I visit the dojo before signing up?
q11.answer: Of course! We encourage prospective students and parents to visit our facilities, meet our instructors, and observe a class. Contact us at (+351) 960 384 090 or direcao@askksa.pt to arrange a visit. You can also start with our 3 free trial classes to experience training firsthand.

q12.question: How long does it take to get a black belt in karate?
q12.answer: Typically 4-6 years of consistent training for adults, though this varies by individual dedication and natural aptitude. At ASKKSA, we focus on proper technique, character development, and deep understanding rather than rushing through ranks. Our grading system follows traditional Japanese standards, and we're proud to have formed many black belts who exemplify the true spirit of karate.
